name: Shanghai's Best
dishnotes1: Really great authentic street-food-style dumplings. You can choose between pan-fried or steamed. Don't forget the soy sauce and chili oil!
dishnotes2: Vegan/vegetarian dumplings are sometimes only available steamed or fried - not both. The vegan ones are favored over the vegetarian option, which contains egg, but they are also great.

name: La Jarocita
dishname1: Carnitas huarache with everything, black beans
dishnotes1: You can't go wrong here, try anything!
dishnotes2: A great cart that offers tofu! Not a very common thing for mexican food, so if you are a veggie burrito lover, this one is worth trying. You can ask for no dairy, and also add potatoes if you wish. They are super nice!

name: Huong's
dishnotes1: Possibly the best-value food deal in PDX. $4 for a full meal-sized sandwich. They will ask if you want peanuts in the sandwich (recommended), presumably for allergy reasons.
dishnotes2: This is the vegetarian alternative to the meat options, but I haven't been able to confirm if it's totally vegan.

name: Rolling Gourmet Fusion
dishnotes1: Seriously, any of them. And any 2 side items. Depending on which rolls you order, this can be a gluten free meal.

name: 808 Grinds
dishnotes1: Or anything, their menu is simple. Even the mac salad is good. Try the different sauces.

name: Gyro Place
dishnotes1: You can also try the kafta gyro if you're not starving (the rice plates are huge and come with salad and hummus).
dishnotes2: This comes with a salad, hummus, rice, falafel, tzaziki, sauces, and pita upon request. Very good food, and super nice folks.

name: Nong's Kao Man Gai
dishnotes1: Delicious pressure-cooked chicken and rice. Comes with a bowl of ginger sauce and a bowl of soup. Order it spicy if you dare! Also: great Thai iced-tea & iced-coffee.

name: Noodle House
dishnotes1: Very high quality handmade everything.
dishnotes2: I confirmed the noodles are vegan. Solid dish for a good price - I like it spicy.

name: E-San
dishnotes1: I think this is the best Pad Thai deal around, these folks know what they're doing (there will likely be a line for this cart). Any of the menu items can be made vegetarian, and also vegan (with no egg or fish sauce). Having tried it all 3 ways, I can say it has been consistently good.
dishnotes2: This is a really tasty stir fry, something a little different that took me a while to try - and now its my favorite! Can be made vegetarian or vegan upon request, also ask for brown rice if you prefer.

name: Grilled Cheese Grill
dishnotes1: Safe comfort food at this cart - anything on the menu is worth trying if it catches your eye. Can be made with vegan substitutions!

name: Tito's Burritos
dishnotes1: One of my favorite places to get a burrito. They really do the So-Cal style justice here in Portland, where that can be hard to find. Salsas are recommended.
dishnotes2: A great take on Al Pastor using soy protein. I recommend requesting guac, and perhaps pico de gallo as well.

name: Wolf and Bear's
dishnotes1: Portland-style Mediterranean food. This wrap has really great fresh veggies (fried egg plant too!), crispy falafel, and some an amazing tahini sauce with hummus.

name: The Whole Bowl
dishnotes1: This is the only thing they serve, in 2 sizes. One of Portland's most popular food carts, with a bunch of locations all over town. The sauce is reknowned and makes a simple dish something special. Can be requested vegan, they will give you extra avocado.

name: Burger Stevens
dishnotes1: Everything at this cart is good, so they get pretty busy during lunch. High quality standard burgers and fries (fries are amazing here). This cart offers a full list of add-ons (avocado, egg, bacon, etc.). The double with fries is a LOT of food, but very good.
dishnotes2: The veggie burger can be made vegan, and it seems like they will put a bit of avocado spread on to compensate for the lack of cheese and sauce. I really like it that way, but they have forgotten a few times.

name: Fried Egg I'm In Love
dishnotes1: Their signature dish, can be made vegatarian with veggie sausage.

name: Stretch the Noodle
dishnotes1: This place is pretty special. The noodles are hand made - right in front of you! Pretty cool to see, but it does take a little bit. Try to avoid lunch rush. Tofu and veggies option is great, but they have meat versions as well.

name: Greenleaf
dishnotes1: You can ask for gluten free oatmeal for an extra few bucks. located off pioneer square. absolutely two meals for the price of one.

name: Tasty n Alder
dishnotes1: Literally anything you get will be good. This place can get full for lunch, but it's great for a more upscale sit-down meal.

name: La Jarocha
dishnotes1: A little bit of a walk, but worth it for a good sit down lunch. The menu doesn't seem to be very vegetarian-friendly but it might be worth calling about.

name: Bamboo Sushi
dishnotes1: A bit expensive, but is known as one of the best places to get sushi in town. This dish can be served with albacore, but it comes vegetarian, and it is very good either way. Without the sauce it is vegan, but I do recommend the sauce.
dishnotes2: An amazing sushi roll designed for vegetarians. They can't call it totally vegan due to the black sesame puree containing honey, but it can be easily made without it.

name: Shigezo
dishnotes1: The menu here is vegetarian, vegan, and gluten-free friendly, just talk to your server. Known for the Ramen, but everything else is good. This is an excellent place for sushi.

name: Habibi
dishnotes1: Great place for a sit-down group lunch, and the menu is very diverse with every section split into vegan, vegetarian and meat. It's a short walk and they usually have a table. Gluten-free folks: talk to your server (but for the most part just avoid the bread).

name: Mayas Taqueria
dishnotes1: Easy place to walk in and order. solid food, burritos come with chips and salsa. Can be requested vegan, and the habenero salsa is excellent.

name: Southpark
dishnotes1: A sit-down that is very close, and serves quality food. They are known for their clam chowder, but I hear pretty much everything else is good too!
dishnotes2: A go-to dish, really delicious. Basically tied with the clam chowder in quality.

name: Darsalam
dishnotes1: Really good buffet style lunch, and affordable. It's a bit of a walk, but still relatively close.

name: Addy's Sandwich Bar
dishnotes1: This sandwich is amazing. I recommend the baguette version for anything, but you can order in various sandwich forms. They have a nice little deli selection of salads and things to choose from.

name: Thai Peacock
dishnotes1: Really great sit down lunch spot, with a full menu. Gets a little busy in there, but I've never had a problem getting a table or seat. Still try to get there around when they open if possible. This is one of the best Thai places in town.

name: Mr. Teriyaki
dishnotes1: Bowls come with rice, soba noodles, veggies, slaw, and potstickers with tasty sauces. The Spicy Chicken is also delicioius.
dishnotes2: Tuna sushi roll with crunchy rice.

name: Stir Fresh
dishnotes1: This place is great for groups, usually a lot of space for seating. Mongolian grill is as expected, and better than others around town. I have never tried the "Hot Pot" there, if that is still a thing they do.

name: Real Taste of India
dishnotes1: Some of the best indian food around, and the naan is very good. Can be a bit oily depending on the dish (e.g. biryani).
dishnotes2: A good vegan/vegetarian option. They are pretty cool about adding things if you request, or even making combinations of things that aren't even on the menu.
